Line 320: Line 320:
===Nurse Kellye===
===Nurse Kellye===
â
[[File:Nurse Kellye.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Kellye Nakahara]]<br> as Nurse Kellye]]
 
'''1st Lt. Kealani Kellye''' was portrayed by [[Kellye Nakahara]]. She appeared in 86 episodes of the series, more episodes than some main characters, such as [[#Henry Blake|Henry Blake]] and [[#Trapper John|Trapper John]]. In her first appearances, her name changed several times before it finally settled on "Nurse Kellye"; for example, she was referred to as "Nurse Able" in her first appearance in "[[M*A*S*H (season 3)|A Full Rich Day]]". The first name "Kealani" was never spoken on screen, but according to interviews with the actress, that was the first name used on set when referring to the character.<ref>http://www.mash4077.co.uk/kelly3.html</ref> As late as season 10, Major Winchester referred to Kellye as "Lt. Nakahara" in "The Birthday Girls."
'''1st Lt. Kealani Kellye''' was portrayed by [[Kellye Nakahara]]. She appeared in 86 episodes of the series, more episodes than some main characters, such as [[#Henry Blake|Henry Blake]] and [[#Trapper John|Trapper John]]. In her first appearances, her name changed several times before it finally settled on "Nurse Kellye"; for example, she was referred to as "Nurse Able" in her first appearance in "[[M*A*S*H (season 3)|A Full Rich Day]]". The first name "Kealani" was never spoken on screen, but according to interviews with the actress, that was the first name used on set when referring to the character.<ref>http://www.mash4077.co.uk/kelly3.html</ref> As late as season 10, Major Winchester referred to Kellye as "Lt. Nakahara" in "The Birthday Girls."
Line 326: Line 325:
===Igor Straminsky===
===Igor Straminsky===
â
[[File:Igor Straminsky.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Jeff Maxwell]] as<br> Igor]]
 
'''Private Igor Straminsky'''<!---When was the name 'Straminsky' ever spoken in the series? --> was generally portrayed by actor [[Jeff Maxwell]], although [[Peter Riegert]] played him in two sixth season episodes. He debuted in the second season and appeared on and off up until the series finale. He has appeared in more episodes than any non-main character except for Nurse Kellye.
'''Private Igor Straminsky'''<!---When was the name 'Straminsky' ever spoken in the series? --> was generally portrayed by actor [[Jeff Maxwell]], although [[Peter Riegert]] played him in two sixth season episodes. He debuted in the second season and appeared on and off up until the series finale. He has appeared in more episodes than any non-main character except for Nurse Kellye.
Line 334: Line 332:
===Luther Rizzo===
===Luther Rizzo===
â
[[File:Luther Rizzo.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[G. W. Bailey]] as<br>Rizzo]]
 
'''Staff Sergeant Luther Rizzo''' was played by [[G. W. Bailey]]. In the show, he was head of the [[fleet vehicle|motor pool]]. While originally written to be from [[New York City]], when the producers heard Bailey in his first [[dailies]] his character was moved to Louisiana.<ref>Memories of M*A*S*H (20th Anniversary) (CBS, 1991), interview with G.W. Bailey</ref> He was known for his slow, deep, Louisiana drawl and his slightly disheveled look. Though the motor pool seemed to function well, it did so despite Rizzo's casual work style and frequent naps. His philosophy on success in the army was that it was possible to never do work, so long as your superiors don't see you enjoy yourself: "Where else [but the Army] can you be a bum and get paid for it?"
'''Staff Sergeant Luther Rizzo''' was played by [[G. W. Bailey]]. In the show, he was head of the [[fleet vehicle|motor pool]]. While originally written to be from [[New York City]], when the producers heard Bailey in his first [[dailies]] his character was moved to Louisiana.<ref>Memories of M*A*S*H (20th Anniversary) (CBS, 1991), interview with G.W. Bailey</ref> He was known for his slow, deep, Louisiana drawl and his slightly disheveled look. Though the motor pool seemed to function well, it did so despite Rizzo's casual work style and frequent naps. His philosophy on success in the army was that it was possible to never do work, so long as your superiors don't see you enjoy yourself: "Where else [but the Army] can you be a bum and get paid for it?"
Line 342: Line 339:
===Sidney Freedman===
===Sidney Freedman===
â
[[File:Sidney Freedman.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Allan Arbus]] as<br>Sidney]]
 
'''Major Sidney Theodore Freedman''', played by [[Allan Arbus]], is a [[psychiatrist]] frequently summoned in cases of [[mental health]] problems; the name is a play on that of psychoanalyst [[Sigmund Freud]]. When Radar was written out of the series, Sidney Freedman was going to join the cast of ''M*A*S*H''. However, Allan Arbus didn't want to commit to be anything other than a guest star, so the character remained an occasionally recurring character.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} In the ''M*A*S*H 30th Anniversary Special'' that aired on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in 2002, Arbus was the only non-regular cast member to be featured on the special.
'''Major Sidney Theodore Freedman''', played by [[Allan Arbus]], is a [[psychiatrist]] frequently summoned in cases of [[mental health]] problems; the name is a play on that of psychoanalyst [[Sigmund Freud]]. When Radar was written out of the series, Sidney Freedman was going to join the cast of ''M*A*S*H''. However, Allan Arbus didn't want to commit to be anything other than a guest star, so the character remained an occasionally recurring character.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} In the ''M*A*S*H 30th Anniversary Special'' that aired on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in 2002, Arbus was the only non-regular cast member to be featured on the special.
Line 354: Line 350:
===Sam Flagg===
===Sam Flagg===
â
[[File:Colonel_Flagg.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Edward Winter (actor)|Edward Winter]] as<br> Col. Flagg]]
 
'''Colonel Sam[uel] Flagg''' is played by actor [[Edward Winter (actor)|Edward Winter]]. Col. Flagg is an American intelligence agent. His behavior is paranoid and irrational and he appears to the staff of the 4077th Mobile Army Surgical Hospital to be mentally unstable; the fact that he deliberately seriously injures himself to advance an investigation seems proof of that. At one point, he tries to get into [[Counterintelligence Corps (United States Army)|Counter Intelligence Corps]] headquarters by crashing his jeep into a brick wall and setting himself on fire (when told this, Hawkeye responds "Is this guy available for kids' parties?") Another time, to get into the 4077th, he orders a helicopter pilot to crash and then twice breaks his own arm.<ref>Episode 48/Season 2</ref> He alternately claims to be affiliated with the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], the [[Counterintelligence Corps (United States Army)|CIC]], or the [[United States Army Criminal Investigation Command|CID]], and occasionally all at once, depending on to whom he is speaking. Example: "I'm with the CIA, but I tell people I'm with the CIC, so they think I'm with the CID." Majors [[#Frank Burns|Frank Burns]] and [[#Margaret Houlihan|Margaret Houlihan]], strong [[anti-communism|anti-Communist]]s, follow his assignments with great interest, but are unable to "buddy up" to him as they hope. As Flagg says, "Nobody can get the truth out of me because even I don't know what it is. I keep myself in a constant state of utter confusion." At some point, however, Major Houlihan loses her respect for Flagg, as revealed in an episode in which she claims that he gives Americans a bad name.
'''Colonel Sam[uel] Flagg''' is played by actor [[Edward Winter (actor)|Edward Winter]]. Col. Flagg is an American intelligence agent. His behavior is paranoid and irrational and he appears to the staff of the 4077th Mobile Army Surgical Hospital to be mentally unstable; the fact that he deliberately seriously injures himself to advance an investigation seems proof of that. At one point, he tries to get into [[Counterintelligence Corps (United States Army)|Counter Intelligence Corps]] headquarters by crashing his jeep into a brick wall and setting himself on fire (when told this, Hawkeye responds "Is this guy available for kids' parties?") Another time, to get into the 4077th, he orders a helicopter pilot to crash and then twice breaks his own arm.<ref>Episode 48/Season 2</ref> He alternately claims to be affiliated with the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], the [[Counterintelligence Corps (United States Army)|CIC]], or the [[United States Army Criminal Investigation Command|CID]], and occasionally all at once, depending on to whom he is speaking. Example: "I'm with the CIA, but I tell people I'm with the CIC, so they think I'm with the CID." Majors [[#Frank Burns|Frank Burns]] and [[#Margaret Houlihan|Margaret Houlihan]], strong [[anti-communism|anti-Communist]]s, follow his assignments with great interest, but are unable to "buddy up" to him as they hope. As Flagg says, "Nobody can get the truth out of me because even I don't know what it is. I keep myself in a constant state of utter confusion." At some point, however, Major Houlihan loses her respect for Flagg, as revealed in an episode in which she claims that he gives Americans a bad name.
Line 366: Line 361:
===Spearchucker Jones===
===Spearchucker Jones===
â
[[File:Spearchucker Jones.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Timothy Brown (actor)|Timothy Brown]] as<br> Spearchucker]]
 
'''Captain Oliver Harmon "Spearchucker" Jones''' or '''Captain Oliver Wendell "Spearchucker" Jones''' was portrayed by [[Fred Williamson]] in the movie and [[Timothy Brown (actor)|Timothy Brown]] in the television series. Spearchucker was shown during several episodes during the first season of the series. His full name was never mentioned in the series. The character's middle name was Harmon in the film and Wendell in the novels. He is a [[Board certification|board-certified]] [[Neurosurgery|neurosurgeon]] in the film, and in the episode in which Hawkeye becomes chief surgeon, Spearchucker's specialty is indicated as he struggles to do surgery and when he asks Hawkeye for help he says "anything outside of the brain and I'm dead".
'''Captain Oliver Harmon "Spearchucker" Jones''' or '''Captain Oliver Wendell "Spearchucker" Jones''' was portrayed by [[Fred Williamson]] in the movie and [[Timothy Brown (actor)|Timothy Brown]] in the television series. Spearchucker was shown during several episodes during the first season of the series. His full name was never mentioned in the series. The character's middle name was Harmon in the film and Wendell in the novels. He is a [[Board certification|board-certified]] [[Neurosurgery|neurosurgeon]] in the film, and in the episode in which Hawkeye becomes chief surgeon, Spearchucker's specialty is indicated as he struggles to do surgery and when he asks Hawkeye for help he says "anything outside of the brain and I'm dead".
Line 378: Line 372:
===Ugly John===
===Ugly John===
â
[[File:UglyJohn1.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[John Orchard]] as<br> Ugly John]]
 
'''Captain "Ugly" John Black''' was portrayed by [[Carl Gottlieb]] in the movie, and [[John Orchard]] in the TV series. The character on the television show was an anesthesiologist from [[Australia]], often depicted wearing an Australian [[Slouch hat]]. In the book, he was an American who had "trained in the States with [[#Trapper John McIntyre|McIntyre]]." In the film, he is an American (as he can be seen wearing the insignia of a U.S. Army Captain), but his background is not discussed.
'''Captain "Ugly" John Black''' was portrayed by [[Carl Gottlieb]] in the movie, and [[John Orchard]] in the TV series. The character on the television show was an anesthesiologist from [[Australia]], often depicted wearing an Australian [[Slouch hat]]. In the book, he was an American who had "trained in the States with [[#Trapper John McIntyre|McIntyre]]." In the film, he is an American (as he can be seen wearing the insignia of a U.S. Army Captain), but his background is not discussed.
In the TV series, Ugly John was only present in the first season. He began as a significant supporting member of the cast, often engaged in poker games with Hawkeye and Trapper, but by the end of the season he was rarely seen outside of brief O.R. scenes.
In the TV series, Ugly John was only present in the first season. He began as a significant supporting member of the cast, often engaged in poker games with Hawkeye and Trapper, but by the end of the season he was rarely seen outside of brief O.R. scenes.
Line 385: Line 378:
===Ho-Jon===
===Ho-Jon===
â
[[File:Ho-Jon.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Patrick Adiarte]] as<br> Ho-Jon]]
 
'''Ho-Jon''' was portrayed by [[Patrick Adiarte]] in the series. In the original novel, Ho-Jon is described as a 17-year-old [[Koreans|Korean]], tall, thin, bright, [[Christian]], and living in [[Seoul]]. He is drafted into the [[South Korea]]n army, subsequently wounded and sent back to the 4077th for treatment. After rehabilitation, he resumes his position as "Swampboy". The Swampmen, who are very fond of Ho-Jon, arrange to have him sent to Hawkeye's old [[college]] in the US. To raise funds, Trapper grows a beard, poses as [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]] (complete with a cross mounted on a jeep or hanging from a helicopter), and autographs thousands of photos which the Swampmen sell for a buck apiece.
'''Ho-Jon''' was portrayed by [[Patrick Adiarte]] in the series. In the original novel, Ho-Jon is described as a 17-year-old [[Koreans|Korean]], tall, thin, bright, [[Christian]], and living in [[Seoul]]. He is drafted into the [[South Korea]]n army, subsequently wounded and sent back to the 4077th for treatment. After rehabilitation, he resumes his position as "Swampboy". The Swampmen, who are very fond of Ho-Jon, arrange to have him sent to Hawkeye's old [[college]] in the US. To raise funds, Trapper grows a beard, poses as [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]] (complete with a cross mounted on a jeep or hanging from a helicopter), and autographs thousands of photos which the Swampmen sell for a buck apiece.
In ''[[M*A*S*H Goes to Maine]]'', Ho-Jon is briefly seen again, having pursued a successful career in university administration. In "[[M*A*S*H Mania]]" he is shown to have become the Director of Admissions at Androscroggin College (Hawkeye's [[alma mater]]).
In ''[[M*A*S*H Goes to Maine]]'', Ho-Jon is briefly seen again, having pursued a successful career in university administration. In "[[M*A*S*H Mania]]" he is shown to have become the Director of Admissions at Androscroggin College (Hawkeye's [[alma mater]]).
Line 398: Line 390:
===Lieutenant Dish===
===Lieutenant Dish===
â
[[File:Lieutenant Dish.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Karen Philipp]] as<br> Lieutenant Dish]]
 
'''1st Lt. Maria "Dish" Schneider''' was played by [[Jo Ann Pflug]] in the film and (as '''Lt. Maggie Dish''') by [[Karen Philipp]] in the series. She was a [[nurse]] at the 4077th [[Mobile Army Surgical Hospital|MASH]] during the [[Korean War]].
'''1st Lt. Maria "Dish" Schneider''' was played by [[Jo Ann Pflug]] in the film and (as '''Lt. Maggie Dish''') by [[Karen Philipp]] in the series. She was a [[nurse]] at the 4077th [[Mobile Army Surgical Hospital|MASH]] during the [[Korean War]].
Line 404: Line 395:
===Donald Penobscot===
===Donald Penobscot===
â
[[File:Donald Penobscot.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Beeson Carroll]] as<br> Donald Penobscot]]
 
'''Lieutenant Colonel Donald Penobscot''' was played by two different actors, [[Beeson Carroll]], and former football player and [[Tarzan]] actor [[Mike Henry (American football)|Mike Henry]]. His last name is perhaps inspired by the [[Penobscot River]] in [[Maine]], the state from where the novel's author, [[Richard Hooker (author)|Richard Hooker]], originally hailed.
'''Lieutenant Colonel Donald Penobscot''' was played by two different actors, [[Beeson Carroll]], and former football player and [[Tarzan]] actor [[Mike Henry (American football)|Mike Henry]]. His last name is perhaps inspired by the [[Penobscot River]] in [[Maine]], the state from where the novel's author, [[Richard Hooker (author)|Richard Hooker]], originally hailed.
Line 416: Line 406:
===Zelmo Zale===
===Zelmo Zale===
â
[[File:Zelmo Zale.jpg|150px|right|thumb|[[Johnny Haymer]] as<br>Zale]]
 
'''Staff Sergeant Zelmo Zale''' was portrayed by Johnny Haymer.<ref>Fred L. Worth, ''Incredible Super Trivia'' (Greenwich House, 1984), [http://books.google.com/books?id =jua6vfXfS6UC&q=%22Zelmo+Zale%22&dq=%22Zelmo+Zale%22&ei=_QGOSareLpj4MPm80LAF&pgis=1 402].</ref> Zale was the supply sergeant<ref>David Scott Diffrient, ''M*A*S*H'' (Wayne State University Press, 2008), [http://books.google.com/books?id=q6PCeV6-IxgC&pg=PT56&dq=%22Zelmo+Zale%22&ei=_QGOSareLpj4MPm80LAF#PPT56,M1 47].</ref> for the 4077th MASH and also was the camp's electrician; he was shown trying to keep the [[Military camp|camp]]'s generator going until it blew and repairing the juke box in the officers' club after the Marines busted it up. He mentions in one episode that he was from Brooklyn, which was the reason he didn't know what people who were heading to California in the late 1840s were looking for, when quizzed. He made his first appearance in the Season 2 episode, "[[M*A*S*H (season 2)|For Want of a Boot]]", and his final appearance in the Season 8 episode, "[[Good-Bye Radar]]" (which, coincidentally enough, also marked [[Gary Burghoff]]'s last appearance on the show as Corporal [[#Radar O'Reilly|Radar O'Reilly]]). Zale's name is mentioned for the final time in "Yes Sir, That's Our Baby".
'''Staff Sergeant Zelmo Zale''' was portrayed by Johnny Haymer.<ref>Fred L. Worth, ''Incredible Super Trivia'' (Greenwich House, 1984), [http://books.google.com/books?id =jua6vfXfS6UC&q=%22Zelmo+Zale%22&dq=%22Zelmo+Zale%22&ei=_QGOSareLpj4MPm80LAF&pgis=1 402].</ref> Zale was the supply sergeant<ref>David Scott Diffrient, ''M*A*S*H'' (Wayne State University Press, 2008), [http://books.google.com/books?id=q6PCeV6-IxgC&pg=PT56&dq=%22Zelmo+Zale%22&ei=_QGOSareLpj4MPm80LAF#PPT56,M1 47].</ref> for the 4077th MASH and also was the camp's electrician; he was shown trying to keep the [[Military camp|camp]]'s generator going until it blew and repairing the juke box in the officers' club after the Marines busted it up. He mentions in one episode that he was from Brooklyn, which was the reason he didn't know what people who were heading to California in the late 1840s were looking for, when quizzed. He made his first appearance in the Season 2 episode, "[[M*A*S*H (season 2)|For Want of a Boot]]", and his final appearance in the Season 8 episode, "[[Good-Bye Radar]]" (which, coincidentally enough, also marked [[Gary Burghoff]]'s last appearance on the show as Corporal [[#Radar O'Reilly|Radar O'Reilly]]). Zale's name is mentioned for the final time in "Yes Sir, That's Our Baby".
